definition: remote/hidden away/secluded/serene/peaceful/to imprison/in superstition indicates the underworld/ancient district spanning Liaonang and Hebei provinces

sentences.english: This book is suffused with Shaw's characteristic wry Irish humour.
sentences.chinese: 这本书充满了萧伯纳独特的爱尔兰式幽默与嘲讽。

sentences.english: We give them a sense of humor because laughter leaven life.
sentences.chinese: 我们要给予他们幽默感，因为笑声可以使生活更轻松。

sentences.english: The funny cunning agent uses his gum gun before aurora or after dusk.
sentences.chinese: 幽默灵巧的赛跑者在日出之前或日落之后使用胶皮枪。

sentences.english: Humour in the ads is a recent innovation, but parodies of them are plentiful.
sentences.chinese: 广告中幽默这一创新出现不久，却被到处效颦。

sentences.english: You can find humor in just about any situation.
sentences.chinese: 几乎在任何情况你都可以找到幽默的。

sentences.english: The Five Humoresques reveal Reger in lighter mode.
sentences.chinese: 五首幽默小品则显示出其轻快的一面。

sentences.english: Learned before, a table personnel, optimistic, cheerful, witty humor.
sentences.chinese: 博学多才，一表人才，开朗乐观，风趣幽默。

sentences.english: If You Are The One keeps the typical humor of Feng Xiaogang.
sentences.chinese: 《非诚勿扰》保留了一贯的“冯式幽默”。

sentences.english: First-class teachers have a good sense of humor.
And we love self-deprecating humor like we saw from the First Lady," says Mr. Lichtman.
sentences.chinese: 我们喜欢第一夫人那种自我解嘲的幽默。

sentences.english: Music can even be used or created to express humor. Musical puns such as those by "P.D.Q.
sentences.chinese: 甚至可以运用或编创音乐来表达幽默。

sentences.english: He has a good clean sense of humour.
sentences.chinese: 他有着高雅而不低俗的幽默感。

sentences.english: Think you know your work setting well enough to tread on this dangerous ground?
sentences.chinese: 你以为你的幽默感好得可以无所忌惮？

sentences.english: Jap training methods are both humorless and tireless.
sentences.chinese: 日本人的训练方法即缺乏幽默感又不知疲倦。
你真是一个十足的幽默家。

sentences.english: It’s possible you’re envious of his sharp sense of humor.
sentences.chinese: 那么，极有可能你嫉妒他机智的幽默。

definition: to amuse/to make sb laugh/to tease
silly talk or "mo lei tau" (Cantonese), genre of humor emerging from Hong Kong late in the 20th century
to include impromptu comic material in opera performance (idiom); to jest/buffoonery
to amuse oneself/to clown around/to provoke laughter
